app.title: üõ∞Ô∏è Impactor-2025: Learn & Simulate
app.caption: An educational dashboard to explore asteroid impacts, built for a hackathon.
app.where_hit: Where does it hit? Pick a city or enter coordinates.
app.population_estimates_note: Population estimates rely on documented synthetic density rings and fall back to the crater footprint when blast rings vanish; replace with real datasets when available.
app.pair_sample_explain: Sample uncertain properties (diameter, density, angle, strength) using the PAIR Monte Carlo approach to explore outcome distributions.
app.pair_note: PAIR = Probabilistic Asteroid Impact Risk (Mathias et al., 2017). Replace assumed distributions with mission-specific priors as data become available.
app.neo_selected_caption: Selected **{name}** ‚Äî avg diameter ‚âà {diameter} m, speed ‚âà {speed} km/s, miss distance ‚âà {miss_km} km (~{moonx}√ó Moon).
app.use_neo_button: Use this NEO in the simulator
app.adjust_strength_caption: Adjust to emulate cohesive strength used in PAIR entry modeling.
app.neo_fetch_unavailable: Could not fetch NEOs right now (API rate limit or offline). You can still use the simulator.
app.neo_pick_prompt: Pick an asteroid to simulate (what-if it hit):

expanders.use_today_neos: Use today's NASA NEOs as inputs

sidebar.disclaimer: This is an educational demo. Numbers are approximate. For real decisions, consult official models and data.

learn.learn_text:
**Kinetic energy** ‚Äî Energy of motion. We convert it to **megatons of TNT** to help compare sizes.

**Crater** ‚Äî A bowl-shaped hole. Our estimate is simplified for learning.

**Deflection (Œîv)** ‚Äî A tiny push far in advance can move an asteroid enough to miss Earth.

**Why simplified?** ‚Äî Real scientists use more complex models (airbursts, fragmentation, terrain, oceans).
Our goal is to **learn the ideas** first‚Äîthen you can add advanced physics.

deflect.caption: Deflection visualization preserves the same damage model; connect to spatial datasets to recalculate exposure for the shifted impact point.
